body:
A key-frame is an orientation state at a given time.
If you specify the same angle, the orientation state is the same in the 2 key-frame.
You cannot have an animation this way.
Axis-Angle, Quaternion, and Rot-Matrix, all represent orientations. An animation is an interpolation between these orientations. 
Increase the number of key-frames.

BTW: use key-frames angles < 180

Agree, this is commonly solved by denser keyframes.

Which application generated the file?

I do agree with you in principle.

However, unfortunately we have no control over the models that users attempt to import using Assimp, and as such one should strive to be as compatible as possible with anything that may be thrown at us, right? Lest they just assume that it's us at fault, rather than the exporter.

Axis-Angle can represent a rotation, not just an orientation, because the angle can be greater than 360 degrees. This will allow proper interpolation between the two values.

The application which exported this file is 3D Studio Max, and the file correctly imports into 3DS, Maya, and Blender with animation intact.

(As a further note, this particular model was given to me by a user of my software complaining that the animation didn't work. I didn't create it. However, I have obtained permission from them for you to include it in the Assimp test library if you wish).

To be lenient with importers is indeed Assimp's policy, the question is which effort it requires ..

Can you provide the file?

Also @Schrompf for the Collada import.

The file was linked to above:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/29850039/Array%20Test%20001.zip

When animated properly, this should produce a cool spinny effect.
Fixed it for Collada, please re-open if needed.

It appears that there was a mis-merge on 14-03-2015 (SHA-1: c59878e427911315d5ef9b75c0c8ccfe551c6944) which overwrote your fix for issue #458.
